title: Help generating InDesign small size pdf
content:
Hi all

I’m using Indesign cs3 to generate a pdf.  
The pdf will contain only a jpg image and i’m trying to get the smallest file size possible for screen display.  
My question is what would be the best way to do it.  
Would it be using the save for web in photoshop and lowering the jpg quality, or would it be best to use a high quality jpg and reduce the image quality in the pdf export settings in Indesign?

I tried both ways, and the results opticaly look practicly the same, but the advantage of photoshop is that it presents a lot more options available using the save for web command.  
Anyway, it’s always nice to now how professionals usually do.

Hope i’m being clear enough.

Thanks in advance  
Regards

comments.content:
I usually just choose ’smallest filesize’ from the presets dropdown menu in the PDF export window. I don’t know if this makes the smallest PDF possible, but small enough for me.

But if the outcome is really important for you in this case, I would just try the different options you describe, and see which method is the most convenient / best. :)

yeah i came across a similar problem when i worked on an online literary journal. i find saving postscript files and converting them with distilller helps a lot. you can even create your own compression script (called .joboptions i think) in distiller to specify just where you want to ’squeeze’ the compression rates and whatever. just go into distiller \> settings \> edit adobe pdf settings and a dialog box comes up with options.

then just make sure when you save as you call it something different to the joboption file you based it on.

if you’ve never used distiller before it’s not very complicated. after you’ve saved the ps file, open distiller, choose the setting from the drop down box (which you should’ve made a new setting for, or else pick one of the defaults) and drag the ps file into distiller.

voila. i garauntee it’ll be smaller than the same file as an exported pdf.
oh, and to save the postscript file you have to go through the file \> print dialog window. it’ll have it as an option under the printer choice.

Saving to the smallest filesize as Quincunx suggested is a pretty good start. You could also change the compatibility to Acrobat 6, it makes the file size a bit smaller, and most people have Acrobat 6 by now.  
Changing compression options at the Export pdf dialogue window helps, too (from the small file default 150 to 72 dpi, for example)

It all depends what your needs are, the Photoshop save for web option isn’t a bad option, either.
This might be a stupid question: have you tried saving as a PDF from Photoshop, bypassing InD entirely?

Thanks to all for your replys.

<cite>have you tried saving as a PDF from Photoshop, bypassing InD entirely?</cite>

:) i’m not building a pdf with just one jpg inside, it was just an example to simplier explain my point.

I guess i’ll just keep testing those different aproaches and see what best works in this case.
